featureContentItems.hed: This Is What Pizza Looks Like Around the World
featureContentItems.dek: Happy National Pizza Day! Celebrate by taking a look at how pies are cooked up in the U.S. and beyond.

shortLinksItems.hed: This Is What Pizza Looks Like Around the World
shortLinksItems.dek: Take a look at how different countries and cities around the world—from New York City to Lebanon—prepare a perfect pizza.
shortLinksItems.seoTitle: This Is What Pizza Looks Like Around the World
shortLinksItems.socialTitle: This Is What Pizza Looks Like Around the World

items.title: Naples, Italy: Neopolitan
items.caption: When most people think of pizza, they probably think of Neopolitan-style pies, with their thin crusts topped with tomatoes (typically San Marzano) and mozzarella cheese. Add a few basil leaves and you have *margherita* pizza, with colors that echo those of the Italian flag.

items.title: __Rome, Italy: Pizza Bianca__
items.caption: This “white pizza”, famous on the streets and in the pizzerias of Rome, is a dressed-down version of the Neopolitan style that's popular farther south. Pizza bianca contains neither of pizza’s two traditional toppings—cheese and tomato sauce—and instead features thin dough drizzled with olive oil and coarse salt, which is then baked and sliced before serving. Fun fact: It's frequently [sold by weight](http://www.cntraveler.com/galleries/2014-10-03/7-things-you-never-knew-about-rome/4), not by slice.

items.title: __New York, NY: New York style__
items.caption: New York-style pizza apes the Neopolitan recipe, but has since become (justly) famous in its own right. The first pizzeria in the U.S., Lombardi's, opened on Spring Street in New York’s Little Italy in 1905, and it didn't take long for other *pizzaiolos*—Grimaldi's, Patsy's, Di Fara—to follow suit. The hallmark of New York–style pizza is its thin, crispy, hand-tossed crust (coal-fired is traditional, but wood and gas have been used too), topped with a light tomato sauce and mozzarella cheese.

items.title: __Chicago, IL: Deep dish__
items.caption: The defining characteristic of Chicago's particular brand of pizza is its crust: Baked in a pan, each pie has a thicker crust that can rise up to three inches high along the edges. Toppings (which often include meat) and cheese are then layered under a chunky tomato sauce. Chicago has a lot of contenders in the race for best slice, but a few of the city’s most famous establishments include [Lou Malnati's](http://www.loumalnatis.com/), [Uno](http://www.unos.com/), and [Gino's East](http://www.ginoseast.com/).

items.title: __Sicily, Italy: *Sfincione* (Sicilian Pizza)__
items.caption: Sicilians tried to fit a square peg in an otherwise round hole in the world of pizza, and the end result is *sfincione.* In Sicily, the pie is topped simply—with some cheese, olive oil, and breadcrumbs—before being baked. The Americanized version of the dish is heavier, with layers of sauce and cheese atop a thick crust.

items.title: __Turkey: Lahmacun__
items.caption: There's some debate over whether *lahmacun* originated in Turkey or Armenia; either way, the end result is a delicious, pizza-esque snack. The name translates loosely to “meat and dough”—and that’s exactly what it is, with minced beef or lamb topping a piece of dough. Other common ingredients include onion, herbs, and tomatoes.

items.title: __Georgia: Khachapuri__
items.caption: *Khachapuri,* a traditional Georgian dish, looks like a calzone crossed with an egg sandwich. The dough is stuffed with cheese (in Georgia, a variety called *sulguni* is often used), then topped with an egg and some butter. (Some restaurants that offer the dish in the U.S. even throw [a whole stick](http://gothamist.com/2014/04/29/khachapuri.php) in there.) And while there are many varieties of this country’s version of pizza, none of them contain tomato sauce.

items.title: __Japan: Okonomiyaki__
items.caption: *Okonomiyaki,* Japan’s take on pizza, is hardly recognizable when compared to the Italian original. The recipe changes based on region, but it typically includes cabbage, pork, noodles, and squid. It’s layered or mixed and fried in batter, then topped with an egg and okonomiyaki sauce, which tastes like a sweeter version of Worcestershire sauce. The place to try it is Hiroshima—the city even has a theme park dedicated to the dish—but you can find okonomiyaki spots throughout the country.

items.title: __France: Tarte Flambee__
items.caption: Leave it to the French to create a pizza-like dish full of the most delicious (and fattening) ingredients: cheese and bacon. Originating from the Alsace region, *tarte flambée* has a thin crust that's topped with *fromage blanc* or *creme fraiche,* *lardons,* and onions, before being baked in a wood-fire oven. There are several varieties in France, including a dessert version with apples, cinnamon, and sweet liqueur.

items.title: __Spain: Coca__
items.caption: This Spanish version of pizza is particularly popular in the Catalonia region of the country. This particular pizza can be served either sweet or savory, and you'll find versions that are both open (a pastry base with toppings) or closed (a hand pie–like pastry with filling). Ingredients vary, and can include egg, fish, vegetables, fruit, meat, and cheese.

items.title: __Lebanon: Manakish__
items.caption: If you've ever eaten a slice of cold pizza for breakfast, then this particular flatbread—which is frequently served as a morning meal—might be for you. The dough is typically topped with za'atar, a spice mixture containing thyme, sesame seeds, and sumac, before baking; it might also have cheese or meat on it.

items.title: __Hungary: Langos__
items.caption: Hungarian *langos* is an especially filling (and—let's be honest—not totally healthy) pizza riff: A piece of deep-fried flat bread is topped with sour cream, meat, or garlic butter. Hungarians and those in neighboring countries like the Czech Republic and Slovakia eat *langos* as a street food.

shortLinksItems.seoDescription: In honor of National Pizza Month, take a look at how different countries and cities around the world—from New York City to Lebanon—prepare a perfect pizza.
shortLinksItems.socialDescription: Take a look at how different countries and cities around the world—from New York City to Lebanon—prepare a perfect pizza.

fields.name: Lauren Kilberg
fields.shortBio: Collector of maps, passport stamps, and freckles.
fields.bio: Lauren Kilberg is a freelance writer and blogger residing in Chicago. Her travels have found her camping near the Pakistani border of India, conquering volcanoes in the Philippines and being humbled in Haiti. She spent two years living and working in South Korea before repatriating to the United States, but not before taking the six-month scenic route home via a backpacking trip from Indonesia to India. In short, she's a collector of maps, passport stamps, and freckles.

shortLinksItems.hed: Spring Hotel Deal: Five Great European Hotels Under $200
shortLinksItems.dek: The Euro is currently at a nine-year low, which means traveling to Europe has not been this affordable for Americans in almost a decade. If you’ve always dreamed of a trip to Europe’s capital cities, now is the time to book. Here are five affordable hotels in European capital cities.
shortLinksItems.seoDescription: If you’ve always dreamed of a trip to Europe’s capital cities, now is the time to book. Here are five affordable hotels in European capital cities.
shortLinksItems.socialDescription: If you’ve always dreamed of a trip to Europe’s capital cities, now is the time to book. Here are five affordable hotels in European capital cities.

items.title: Campo De' Fiori
items.caption:
__[Rome, Italy](http://www.hotelcampodefiori.com/en/default.html)__

Located in its namesake neighborhood, this is a cozy, charming boutique hotel with a façade covered in ivy. Inside, the décor is Baroque but not too precious. It’s shabby chic with a lived-in elegance. A beautiful antique fireplace is in the main hall, which is especially lovely in the winter season, and other common areas include the reading room and library.
The hotel is less than a 10-minute walk from Piazza Navona and the Pantheon. Don’t miss the 360-degree view from the terrace on top of the hotel. *March 16–20: $133/night*

items.title: Hotel Georgette
items.caption:
__[Paris, France](http://www.hotelgeorgette.com/uk/hotel-boutique-paris-beaubourg-site-officiel.php)__

This modern hotel has a great location in the heart of the Marais: It's just blocks away from [Centre Pompidou](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/paris/centre-pompidou), which is currently hosting a massive Jeff Koons retrospective. Georgette's modern design is inspired, in part, by that famed art museum.

Each of the 19 rooms has a different art theme, from New Realism to street art. Rooms are small but clean and comfortable, and include free Wi-Fi; there's also a full breakfast offered each morning by buffet or delivered to your room. *March 16–20: $178/night *

items.title: Olivia Balmes
items.caption:
__[Barcelona, Spain](http://www.oliviabalmeshotel.es/)__

This modern hotel with great amenities is a quarter mile from Barcelona's Passeig de Gracia, one of the main thoroughfares. The rooms are bright and comfortable, many of them with balconies; they're perfect for either business or pleasure.

The hotel also has a beautiful outdoor pool that overlooks the city. It's a leisurely walk or a short metro ride to view some of Barcelona's highlights, including the [Museu Picasso](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/barcelona/museu-picasso) and buildings by Gaudi (Casa Mila and Sagrada Familia among them). *$155/night*

items.title: The Augustine Hotel
items.caption:
__[Prague, Czech Republic](http://cntraveler.com/hotels/czech-republic/prague/the-augustine)__

This hotel is located on the Mala Strana—or “little side”—of the Vltava river, at the base of the hill in Old Town that's home to the historic Prague Castle.

It's not only in a historic building—a former monastery from the 13th century with vaulted ceilings—but is also well appointed and comfortable for travelers of all ages. Plus, there’s a beer bar in the basement of what was the original St. Thomas brewery. *$176/night in March*

items.title: Casa da Calcada
items.caption:
__[Near Porto, Portugal](http://www.casadacalcada.com/pt)__

Technically, this one isn't in a city—it’s about 40 minutes from the city of Porto, not far from the Douro valley—but it is a stunning luxury villa property that offers a relaxing getaway.

The hotel produces Vinho Verde wines and offers tours of local wineries; there's also a beautiful outdoor swimming pool as well as a nearby golf course. Add to that the fact that the on-site Palace Square Restaurant has a Michelin star, and it may be hard to believe you can stay here for less than $200 per night. *March 16–20: $194/night*

shortLinksItems.seoTitle: Spring Hotel Deal: Five Great European Hotels Under $200
shortLinksItems.socialTitle: Spring Hotel Deal: Five Great European Hotels Under $200

fields.name: Gaia Filicori
fields.shortBio: Gaia Filicori is Associate Director of Communications at *Condé Nast Traveler*.
fields.bio:
Born and raised in NYC, Gaia has lived in Prague, Budapest, and Italy. Her most memorable travel experiences include the overnight train to Sarajevo, fabric shopping in Accra, and late raki nights in Beyoglu.  

Dream trip: to see the ruins of Sicily and Tunisia (ancient Carthage).

shortLinksItems.hed: How to Celebrate Mardi Gras Like a Local
shortLinksItems.dek: Mardi Gras can seem like a tourist spectacle, but its pleasures are less about watching the action than being part of it. That’s why New Orleanians throw so much effort into making costumes, riding in parades, and mingling with the crowds. Here’s how you, too, can celebrate like a local.

items.title: [Intergalactic Krewe of Chewbacchus](www.chewbacchus.org)
items.caption: In just its fourth year, the sci-fi mashup krewe expects to attract more than 1,000 fans of Star Wars, *Doctor Who,* Japanese monster films, and other pop icons and cult classics for its [parade through the Bywater and Marigny neighborhoods](www.chewbacchus.org). Peter Mayhew (who played Chewbacca in the original Star Wars) is scheduled to ride a Millennium Falcon replica built on a golf cart. *February 7*

items.title: [’tit Rex](http://titrexparade.com/)
items.caption: Going against all Mardi Gras stereotypes (i.e. bigger, brighter, excess, excess, excess), the young artists that founded this parade have instead scaled down. The parade of artistically crafted shoebox floats—like those made by area school children—is a walking cocktail party in the Marigny neighborhood (www.titresparade.com). One krewe member usually distributes painted cocktail umbrellas to spectators to wave during the festivities. *February 7*

items.title: [Barkus](www.barkus.org)
items.caption: Barkus (a pun on Bacchus) draws thousands to the French Quarter to watch its massive costumed dog walk. Once only attended by a small group of French Quarter dog lovers and their pooches, the parade now welcomes thousands of participants from throughout the city and suburbs. It’s the most family-friendly parade as well as the friendliest day to stroll the Quarter during Carnival. This year, the krewe’s parade is [Star Wars-themed](www.barkus.org)—it's called “Bark Wars: Return of the K-9”—and there's pre- and post-parade socializing in Louis Armstrong Park. *February 8*

items.title: [Muses](http://kreweofmuses.org)
items.caption: Forget beads; some of the most prized items in Carnival are the hand-glittered shoes given out by riders of the all-women [Krewe of Muses](http://kreweofmuses.org). The 14-year-old krewe helped energize parading with the satirical wit and creativity of its themes and floats, from mocking hypocritical “family values” politicians to celebrating shopping. *February 12*

items.title: [Go to a Mardi Gras ball](www.kreweoforpheus.com)
items.caption: Attending most Carnival organizations’ masquerade and coronation balls requires an invitation, but some of them are open to the general public—including the Krewe of Orpheus, founded by New Orleans native [Harry Connick Jr.](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2013-06-13/travel-tips-harry-connick-jr) The group sells tickets to its [Orpheuscapade](www.kreweoforpheus.com), which is meant to be a glitzy, music-infused extravaganza that happens to have a float parade roll through it. *February 16*

items.title: Rex and Zulu Parades
items.caption: For a dose of Carnival tradition, join the encampment on St. Charles Avenue on the morning of Fat Tuesday to watch a double-header of Carnival's most prominent parading organizations. Rex, a 150-year old group of prominent businessmen and socially connected families, puts on one of Mardi Gras's most beautiful processions. The African-American Zulu Social Aid & Pleasure Club started parading more than a century ago in parody of the old-line krewes’ wealth and Carnival grandeur, but it's now one of the city's premier cultural organizations. *February 17*

items.title: Mardi Gras Indians
items.caption: Early on Fat Tuesday, Mardi Gras Indian tribes come out early, strutting new suits covered in brightly colored ostrich plumes and detailed beaded panels. Many tribes make their way to Hunters Field to greet fellow chiefs and tribal figures and compare craftwork. There are no published routes, so Indian fans gravitate to the festivities on North Claiborne Avenue under the I-10 overpass late in the afternoon to await the spectacle. It's a vibrant, street-level tradition with a heavy influence on the city's music and parading culture. *February 17*

items.title: Costume with the [Society of St. Anne](http://kreweofsaintanne.org/)
items.caption: Masking and costuming is a gateway to revelry, even for people just getting started with a feather boa and opera-style mask. The secretive Society of St. Anne sets the standard for lavish costuming. Throw on something festive (there are many costume shops to choose from in the Quarter) on the morning of Fat Tuesday and join the costumers in the Marigny and Bywater neighborhoods who wait for St. Anne to march by. *February 17*

items.title: Bourbon Street Awards
items.caption: *RuPaul's Drag Race* season six winner Bianca Del Rio hosts this annual costume contest, which happens on Fat Tuesday at Bourbon Street's epicenter of gay bars (St. Ann and Bourbon Streets). Aside from the masquerade and tableaux balls hosted by gay Carnival organizations (some of which are invite-only), this is the best place to see drag queens in some of Carnival’s most amazing, outlandish costumes. *February 17*

items.title: Find a King Cake
items.caption: Dining out can be hit or miss during the final crush of Mardi Gras. Locals generally avoid places that shift to severely abbreviated “Mardi Gras menus,” which tend to offer chow-line fare at jacked-up prices. But one thing you’ll find everywhere, from house parties to office break rooms, is king cake—generally a cinnamon coffee cake covered in purple-, green- and gold-colored sugar. The cake contains a tiny plastic baby, and traditionally, the person drawing the piece with the baby becomes the king or queen of the party. In practice, the recipient is obligated to supply the next king cake.

shortLinksItems.seoTitle: How to Celebrate Mardi Gras Like a Local
shortLinksItems.seoDescription: Though the activity on Bourbon Street gets the most attention from the outside world, there’s more to Mardi Gras than beads and beer. Here’s how to do it like an insider.
shortLinksItems.socialTitle: How to Celebrate Mardi Gras Like a Local
shortLinksItems.socialDescription: Though the activity on Bourbon Street gets the most attention from the outside world, there’s more to Mardi Gras than beads and beer. Here’s how to do it like an insider.

fields.name: Will Coviello
fields.shortBio: Will Coviello lives in New Orleans and writes about culture, arts and entertainment.
fields.bio: Will Coviello grew up in New Jersey, went to Mardi Gras in 1992 and has lived in New Orleans most of the time since. He is the arts and entertainment editor for Gambit and has contributed to *The Times-Picayune, Southern Exposure* and other publications.

That’s why New Orleanians throw so much effort into making costumes, riding in parades, and mingling with the crowds. Here’s how you, too, can celebrate like a local.

items.title: [Intergalactic Krewe of Chewbacchus](www.chewbacchus.org)
items.caption: In just its fourth year, the sci-fi mashup krewe expects to attract more than 1,000 fans of Star Wars, *Doctor Who,* Japanese monster films, and other pop icons and cult classics for its [parade through the Bywater and Marigny neighborhoods](www.chewbacchus.org). Peter Mayhew (who played Chewbacca in the original Star Wars) is scheduled to ride a Millennium Falcon replica built on a golf cart. *February 7*

items.title: [’tit Rex](http://titrexparade.com/)
items.caption: Going against all Mardi Gras stereotypes (i.e. bigger, brighter, excess, excess, excess), the young artists that founded this parade have instead scaled down. The parade of artistically crafted shoebox floats—like those made by area school children—is a walking cocktail party in the Marigny neighborhood (www.titresparade.com). One krewe member usually distributes painted cocktail umbrellas to spectators to wave during the festivities. *February 7*

items.title: [Barkus](www.barkus.org)
items.caption: Barkus (a pun on Bacchus) draws thousands to the French Quarter to watch its massive costumed dog walk. Once only attended by a small group of French Quarter dog lovers and their pooches, the parade now welcomes thousands of participants from throughout the city and suburbs. It’s the most family-friendly parade as well as the friendliest day to stroll the Quarter during Carnival. This year, the krewe’s parade is [Star Wars-themed](www.barkus.org)—it's called “Bark Wars: Return of the K-9”—and there's pre- and post-parade socializing in Louis Armstrong Park. *February 8*

items.title: [Muses](http://kreweofmuses.org)
items.caption: Forget beads; some of the most prized items in Carnival are the hand-glittered shoes given out by riders of the all-women [Krewe of Muses](http://kreweofmuses.org). The 14-year-old krewe helped energize parading with the satirical wit and creativity of its themes and floats, from mocking hypocritical “family values” politicians to celebrating shopping. *February 12*

items.title: [Go to a Mardi Gras ball](www.kreweoforpheus.com)
items.caption: Attending most Carnival organizations’ masquerade and coronation balls requires an invitation, but some of them are open to the general public—including the Krewe of Orpheus, founded by New Orleans native [Harry Connick Jr.](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2013-06-13/travel-tips-harry-connick-jr) The group sells tickets to its [Orpheuscapade](www.kreweoforpheus.com), which is meant to be a glitzy, music-infused extravaganza that happens to have a float parade roll through it. *February 16*

items.title: Rex and Zulu Parades
items.caption: For a dose of Carnival tradition, join the encampment on St. Charles Avenue on the morning of Fat Tuesday to watch a double-header of Carnival's most prominent parading organizations. Rex, a 150-year old group of prominent businessmen and socially connected families, puts on one of Mardi Gras's most beautiful processions. The African-American Zulu Social Aid & Pleasure Club started parading more than a century ago in parody of the old-line krewes’ wealth and Carnival grandeur, but it's now one of the city's premier cultural organizations. *February 17*

items.title: Mardi Gras Indians
items.caption: Early on Fat Tuesday, Mardi Gras Indian tribes come out early, strutting new suits covered in brightly colored ostrich plumes and detailed beaded panels. Many tribes make their way to Hunters Field to greet fellow chiefs and tribal figures and compare craftwork. There are no published routes, so Indian fans gravitate to the festivities on North Claiborne Avenue under the I-10 overpass late in the afternoon to await the spectacle. It's a vibrant, street-level tradition with a heavy influence on the city's music and parading culture. *February 17*

items.title: Costume with the [Society of St. Anne](http://kreweofsaintanne.org/)
items.caption: Masking and costuming is a gateway to revelry, even for people just getting started with a feather boa and opera-style mask. The secretive Society of St. Anne sets the standard for lavish costuming. Throw on something festive (there are many costume shops to choose from in the Quarter) on the morning of Fat Tuesday and join the costumers in the Marigny and Bywater neighborhoods who wait for St. Anne to march by. *February 17*

items.title: Bourbon Street Awards
items.caption: *RuPaul's Drag Race* season six winner Bianca Del Rio hosts this annual costume contest, which happens on Fat Tuesday at Bourbon Street's epicenter of gay bars (St. Ann and Bourbon Streets). Aside from the masquerade and tableaux balls hosted by gay Carnival organizations (some of which are invite-only), this is the best place to see drag queens in some of Carnival’s most amazing, outlandish costumes. *February 17*

items.title: Find a King Cake
items.caption: Dining out can be hit or miss during the final crush of Mardi Gras. Locals generally avoid places that shift to severely abbreviated “Mardi Gras menus,” which tend to offer chow-line fare at jacked-up prices. But one thing you’ll find everywhere, from house parties to office break rooms, is king cake—generally a cinnamon coffee cake covered in purple-, green- and gold-colored sugar. The cake contains a tiny plastic baby, and traditionally, the person drawing the piece with the baby becomes the king or queen of the party. In practice, the recipient is obligated to supply the next king cake.

featureContentItems.seoTitle: How to Celebrate Mardi Gras Like a Local
featureContentItems.seoDescription: Though the activity on Bourbon Street gets the most attention from the outside world, there’s more to Mardi Gras than beads and beer. Here’s how to do it like an insider.
featureContentItems.socialTitle: How to Celebrate Mardi Gras Like a Local
featureContentItems.socialDescription: Though the activity on Bourbon Street gets the most attention from the outside world, there’s more to Mardi Gras than beads and beer. Here’s how to do it like an insider.

fields.name: Will Coviello
fields.shortBio: Will Coviello lives in New Orleans and writes about culture, arts and entertainment.
fields.bio: Will Coviello grew up in New Jersey, went to Mardi Gras in 1992 and has lived in New Orleans most of the time since. He is the arts and entertainment editor for Gambit and has contributed to *The Times-Picayune, Southern Exposure* and other publications.

featureContentItems.hed: Spiaggia Urbani: The Italian Beach Only Locals Know About
featureContentItems.dek: Every year thousands of visitors flock to Italy for its unrivaled combination of scenery and food, which is why areas such as Tuscany and Umbria have been on the grid for years. But if you’re looking to avoid crowds and get a true local experience, head to Sirolo’s Urbani beach.
featureContentItems.seoTitle: Spiaggia Urbani: The Italian Beach Only Locals Know About
featureContentItems.seoDescription: Escape to Urbani beach in Italy’s Marche region, the secret spot locals don’t want you to know about.
featureContentItems.socialTitle: The Italian Beach Only Locals Know About
featureContentItems.socialDescription: Escape to Urbani beach in Italy’s Marche region, the secret spot locals don’t want you to know about.

items.caption: The town of Sirolo is located in the Marche region on the eastern side of Italy, perfect for travelers looking for a more low-key slice of the country. Sirolo has seven featured beaches, some of which are only accessible by boat. But if you’re looking for picture-perfect cliff scenes with the added benefit of car access and seaside restaurants, head to Urbani beach.

Urbani is a light gray, pebbled beach with a backdrop of limestone cliffs and pine trees. The atmosphere is classically Italian—laid back and full of local families, with an emphasis on eating well and taking things slowly.

You can access the beach by stopping at one of Sirolo’s parking areas, then carefully navigating your way down the steep hills to the bay. On your way down, don’t miss the opportunity to pause at the strategically placed overlook platforms with stunning views of the coastline.
Once you reach the beach, you’ll notice the blue and white striped sun beds lining up in uniform on the hard stones, paired with matching umbrellas.
There are also retro-looking changing rooms, each marked with a single letter, evoking images of an English seaside town from the 1950s.
The surrounding Adriatic Sea is sheltered and calm, perfect for a relaxing dip in the bay. Swim out farther to the cluster of protruding rocks for a little cliff jumping.

The main event of the day will be your beachside lunch in one of the few restaurants on Urbani beach. These simple and unfussy establishments serve fresh seafood dishes along with traditional pastas and Greek salads. Feast on grilled snapper, fritto misto, mussels in garlic with lemon, and juicy tomato salads. Like the food, the wine is cheap and plentiful, sourced locally from the Marche area and served in glass carafes. And, of course, no meal is complete without a strong Italian espresso to finish.

Here are some tips to help you plan your day (or days) at Urbani:

__Getting there:__ The closest airport is [Ancona Falconara Airport](http://www.aeroportodiancona.net/), which is about a 30-minute drive from Sirolo. It welcomes flights from London Stansted via Ryanair. 

__When to visit:__ July and August is high summer, when you should be guaranteed good weather. July is the better month, as August is when most Italians are on holiday so the beaches will be busiest. June and September are quieter months, but you can still enjoy warm days then.

__What to wear:__ Women parade the beaches in elegant swimsuits paired with wide-brimmed straw hats and large sunglasses. For men, the uniform is almost strictly Speedos. 

__What to read:__ *[A Room With a View](http://www.amazon.com/Room-View-E-M-Forster/dp/1482694573/ref=la_B004N8Z5NM_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1412893619&sr=1-1)* by E. M Forster (1908). The book's heroine, Lucy Honeychurch, rejects her Victorian upbringing and falls in love while on holiday in Italy. It's a classic novel that is both romantic and funny, all while inspiring you to live *la dolce vita*.

fields.name: Anna Chittenden
fields.shortBio: Anna Chittenden is the founder and explorer behind [Lost Guides,](http://www.thelostguides.com/) an online travel guide destination for Asia and beyond.
fields.bio: Anna Chittenden is the founder and explorer behind [Lost Guides,](http://www.thelostguides.com/) an online travel guide destination for Asia and beyond. She created the site for today’s global traveller, who is more interested in experiences rather than expenses, as well as having an eye for quality, design, and authenticity. Since moving from London to Singapore in 2014, she loves that it is always summer. She’s forever on the move with a suitcase in hand, or plotting her next trip.

featureContentItems.hed: 7 Dishes You Must Try in Hong Kong
featureContentItems.dek: A trip to Hong Kong just isn’t complete without a foray into its sprawling food scene—but where to begin? Here are some suggestions on how to sate your palate in Hong Kong.
featureContentItems.seoTitle: 7 Dishes You Must Try in Hong Kong
featureContentItems.seoDescription: Brave enough to eat chicken feet? Try these seven dishes on your next trip to Hong Kong.
featureContentItems.socialTitle: 7 Dishes You Must Try in Hong Kong
featureContentItems.socialDescription: A trip to Hong Kong just isn’t complete without a foray into its sprawling food scene—here's where to start.

items.title: Siu Mai
items.caption: This staple of Cantonese cuisine is also the hallmark of a dim sum brunch. Typically stuffed with ground pork (though there are other incarnations, including a ground shrimp version), this open-faced dumpling is frequently garnished with crab roe and offers the perfect opportunity to practice your chopstick technique.

items.title: Yellow fish balls
items.caption: Look no further than the nearest street-food stall for this treat. Yellow fish balls are made from a mixture of fish and flour pounded into a paste, rolled into a ball, then boiled in a spicy curry sauce until it reaches golden perfection; this snack is an excellent energy booster for travelers on the go. Fish balls are typically served on a bamboo skewer in sets of five to eight, which makes them easily shareable—though you’ll probably want to keep them all to yourself.

items.title: Pineapple bun
items.caption: Fun fact: Pineapple buns, a calorie-filled confection that's wildly popular in Hong Kong, don’t actually contain any pineapple. Instead, the pastry gets its name from the puffy, sugar-covered top half, which some say bears a strong resemblance to the tropical fruit. Slice one open and add a dollop of butter before eating for maximum flavor.

items.title: Char Siu
items.caption: Get your daily dose of protein by digging into a plate of *char siu,* otherwise known as Cantonese-style barbecue pork. The meat is grilled, cut into thin strips, and then coated with a special mixture of honey, soy sauce, and hoisin sauce. Though best accompanied with rice, char siu is so good, it can stand on its own.

items.title: Milk tea
items.caption: Satisfy your thirst with milk tea, the afternoon drink that originated in Hong Kong. It's a mix of black tea with evaporated or condensed milk, and is said to be most authentic when the tea leaves are filtered by a sackcloth bag.

items.title: Egg tart
items.caption: There’s no better way to indulge your sweet tooth in Hong Kong than by having a piping hot egg tart. This ubiquitous creation—not to be confused with *pastel de nata,* the Portuguese version found in neighboring Macau—entices with its wobbly custard center and pastry crust. If you have the time (and space in your stomach), be sure to try both types of the Hong Kong egg tart: one has a crumbly shortbread crust, while the other’s base is of the flaky, puff pastry variety.

items.title: Chicken feet
items.caption: Given their gelatinous texture and plethora of small bones, chicken feet might not be the most convenient thing to eat in Hong Kong. But if you’re an adventurous foodie, this dish comes highly recommended. Eat them in a soup, or deep-fried and stewed in black bean or abalone sauce.

fields.name: Oneika Raymond
fields.shortBio: Oneika Raymond is an educator, writer, and travel junkie who chronicles her adventures abroad on her blog [Oneika the Traveller](http://www.oneika-the-traveller.com/).
fields.bio: Oneika Raymond is an educator, writer, and travel junkie who has travelled to 70 countries on 6 continents. She chronicles her adventures abroad on her blog, [Oneika the Traveller](http://www.oneika-the-traveller.com/), and has also been featured in a number of online publications including *National Geographic, Ebony,* and *The Huffington Post*. Originally from Canada, she is a serial expat who has lived in France, Mexico, Hong Kong, and the UK. A thrill-seeker who is always in the midst of planning her next trip, Oneika has, amongst other things, trekked in Nepal, sailed in Croatia, and gone on safari in Tanzania.

featureContentItems.hed: How to Shop Dubai Like a Fashion Editor
featureContentItems.dek: With these inside tips from the Coveteur, Dubai can become a high-end playground for any shopping fanatic.
featureContentItems.seoTitle: How to Shop Dubai Like a Fashion Editor
featureContentItems.seoDescription: With these inside tips from The Coveteur, Dubai can become a high-end playground for any shopping fanatic.
featureContentItems.socialTitle: How to Shop Dubai Like a Fashion Editor
featureContentItems.socialDescription: With these inside tips from The Coveteur, Dubai can become a high-end playground for any shopping fanatic.
featureContentItems.body:
[#image: /photos/53fb3624a5a7650f3959d073]|||
An array of fashion finds at S*uce|||





What can you likely find us doing between photo shoots and meetings and dinners? Why, shopping, of course! Over the past handful of years, we've mastered the art of making any city a shopping destination. Trust us—where there's a will, there's a way (especially when that will has to do with burning through our credit card limits).

When in Dubai, which is essentially a very expensive amusement park for the 18+ crowd, no will is necessary. In fact, you should actually use your willpower to stay *away* from the shops (if that's even possible), as the pull to pick up an extra suitcase's worth of designer duds is magnetic. Here, find our guide to the best shopping in Dubai—but if you have to pay for heavy baggage fees flying home, don't blame us.

**[S\*uce](http://shopatsauce.com/)**

How to best describe S\*uce? It's kind of like the UAE's version of legendary Parisian concept store [Colette](http://www.colette.fr/), but in multiples—you can find five in Dubai, which go by quirky monikers like S\*uce in the Hood and S\*uce on Sea. Picture offbeat tchotchkes and accessories, ranging from bejeweled clutches in the shape of a Fanta can to Bambi figurines to ball caps with plush dinosaurs on the brim. The boutiques also carry healthy helpings of Isabel Marant, Shourouk, Mawi, Isa Arfen, Sacai, and Ek Thongprasert—otherwise known as everything we want to wear right now. And if you're really in a "surprise me!" mood, they have a vending machine for presents, which really must be seen to be believed. *(Multiple locations; +971 4 346 3393)*


[#image: /photos/53fb362381424d9d655bcb4d]|||
Colorful bags at S*uce's Dubai Mall location|||





**[The Gold Souk](http://www.city-of-gold.com/)**

Go to the Gold Souk to get a taste of traditional Middle Eastern shopping. And by traditional, we mean a massive marketplace filled with nothing but gold…on gold on gold on gold. Do as we do and bring along a magpie _Vogue_ editor like Lynn Yeager to guide you through the bartering process. She returned to the stall selling her prized buy three times before she got her desired price. When it comes to these trinkets, it's all in the negotiation. *(Al Sabkha Road, Al Dhagaya)*

**[Mahani](http://www.mahanifashion.com/)**

This avant-garde concept store carries enough insider-y labels to keep even the most discerning fashion snob flipping through their racks. Rodarte, Simone Rocha, J.W. Anderson, and Junya Watanabe are all well represented. Think of this store as the artsy antidote to Dubai's flash (without losing any of the luxury factor). *(The Boulevard, Jumeirah Emirates Towers; +971 4 351 4812)*


[#image: /photos/53fb3624a5a7650f3959d072]|||
Level Shoe District at the Dubai Mall|||





**[Level Shoe District](http://www.levelshoedistrict.com/)**

This shoe store puts all major department store shoe floors to shame. Stock up on rare Alaïa and Altuzarra stilettos and then disappear under a pile of shoeboxes in the Prada, Dior, and Louis Vuitton boutiques—when we visited, we kind of felt like we were the fashion-girl equivalents of "Keep 'em coming" bar patrons. But be warned: It's much harder to find space for shoes in already overstuffed bags than it is for clothes. *(The Dubai Mall; +971 4 501 6888)*

**[Symphony](http://bysymphony.com/)**

Symphony is the place to go for the full look: Chalayan jacket with Jason Wu blouse with Frame Denim jeans with Alexander McQueen skull-bedecked stilettos. And then throw in a Marchesa gown for good measure. Why not? Dubai is all about excess, and that shouldn't stop at shopping. When in, uh, Rome, right? *(The Dubai Mall; +971 0 4 330 8050)*


[#image: /photos/53fb3623a5a7650f3959d063]|||
The Chanel boutique at Level Shoe District|||

fields.title: dubai-shop-like-a-fashion-editor-sauce-3.jpg
fields.caption: Colorful bags at S*uce's Dubai Mall location.

fields.name: The Coveteur
fields.shortBio: [The Coveteur](http://www.thecoveteur.com/) began as a passion project exploring the homes and closets of global street style stars and tastemakers, and has evolved into exploring all things behind-the-scenes: lifestyle, fashion, and culture.
fields.bio:
[The Coveteur](http://www.thecoveteur.com/) began as a passion project exploring the homes and closets of global street style stars and tastemakers, and has evolved into exploring all things behind-the-scenes: lifestyle, fashion, and culture. With an emphasis on highly personalized curation, The Coveteur goes one step further in examining the creative process, inspiration and influence of the individuals who are defining the zeitgeist of our times.

Founded by Stephanie Mark and Jake Rosenberg in 2011, The Coveteur pulls back the curtain on heretofore unseen adventures in style, travel, arts and culture and exposes what you’ve always wanted to see: an intimate and voyeuristic look at today's influencers.

featureContentItems.hed: How to Stay Comfortable (and Stylish) On Red-Eye Flights
featureContentItems.dek: While it's tempting to wear sweats on red-eye flights, there are other clothing options that will keep you both comfortable and stylish.
featureContentItems.seoTitle: How to Stay Comfortable (and Stylish) On Red-Eye Flights
featureContentItems.socialTitle: How to Stay Comfortable (and Stylish) On Red-Eye Flights

items.caption: Red-eye flights aren’t exactly the most ideal form of travel. Sure, you’ll save money and arrive with a full day’s worth of activities ahead of you, but you’ll have to make do with trading in your bed for a tiny, uncomfortable plane seat. While this makes it tempting to throw on some sweatpants, there are other options that will keep you looking nice and comfortable, and help you avoid having to make a long pit stop at your hotel upon arrival.

items.title: Comfortable classics
items.caption:
The key to dressing for any flight is to be comfortable without looking like you just rolled out of bed. Opt for classic pieces that will have you ready for anything once you arrive; you won’t want to waste time at the hotel when there’s exploring to do. I tend to stick to classic pieces with a neutral color palette. It’s a pretty fool-proof way to not look like a tourist everywhere you go. 
_____
Equipment Brett Silk Blouse *([shopbop.com](http://www.shopbop.com/brett-blouse-equipment/vp/v=1/845524441901731.htm?folderID=2534374302168584&fm=other-shopbysize-viewall&colorId=12867); $198)*

Madewell Skinny Skinny Jeans *([madewell.com](https://www.madewell.com/madewell_category/DENIMBAR/PRDOVR~B0574/B0574.jsp); $115)*

items.title: Layers
items.caption:
While dressing in layers is smart for all flights (planes are always cold), it’s also a great way to be prepared for any occasion. Whether you encounter a change in weather or need to be ready for a business brunch, you can dress up or stay warm in layers. Throw on a trench coat or blazer—I’ve been personally gravitating towards my denim jacket—and you’ll be ready to go. 
_____
Rag & Bone Denim Jacket *([shopbop.com](http://www.shopbop.com/denim-jacket-rag-bone-jean/vp/v=1/845524441949536.htm?folderID=2534374302066387&fm=other-shopbysize-viewall&colorId=46760); $253)*

items.title: Beauty routine
items.caption:
When it comes to your hair and makeup, my motto is, easier is better. Your face and hair are the first things to get messed up during your flight—you will be sleeping (or trying to), after all. The best way to prepare for is to pick a style that won’t look bad if it gets a bit tousled. I usually use this as an excuse to wear a hat. Not only will I not have to worry about packing it, but it’s also an easy way to cover up crazy plane hair. As for your makeup, try and keep it light. You can always touch up before your descent. 
_____
Rag & Bone Wide Brim Fedora *([shopbop.com](http://www.shopbop.com/wide-brim-fedora-rag-bone/vp/v=1/1571419729.htm?folderID=2534374302164858&fm=other-viewall&colorId=12560); $195)*

items.title: Carry-on bag
items.caption:
I’ve never been one to tote around a large carry-on. Lugging around totes and backpacks will only leave you feeling more bogged down after a long day of traveling. I usually limit myself to a small tote, which gives me a limit to how much I can carry and also helps me avoid the whole looking-like-a-tourist thing. Leave room for your jacket, a small cosmetics bag, and a sleep aid.
_____
Madewell Mini Transport Crossbody *([madewell.com](https://www.madewell.com/madewell_category/BAGS/totes/PRDOVR~B2545/B2545.jsp?color_name=true-black); $148)*

items.title: Accessories
items.caption:
A great way to keep your outfit looking put-together is by wearing jewelry during your flight. I always feel safer wearing it rather than packing it anyway, but it comes with the added bonus of making you look a bit more polished. I usually end up wearing my everyday jewelry, such as a few rings, a watch, and necklaces—pieces that tend to go with anything.
_____
Daniel Wellington Classic Sheffield Watch *([danielwellington.com](http://www.danielwellington.com/us/classic-sheffield-209); $199)*

items.title: Shoes
items.caption:
As for shoes, you can’t go wrong with a black boot. This wardrobe staple is easy to slide off at security, comfortable enough for a day of sightseeing, and sharp enough to look professional. Traveling in my black boots proves again why they’re my favorite item in my wardrobe. 
_____
UGG Jo Boots *([uggaustralia.com](http://www.uggaustralia.com/women-boots/jo/1005930.html?dwvar_1005930_color=CHO#start=1&cgid=women-boots); $175)*

featureContentItems.seoDescription: While it's tempting to wear sweats on red-eye flights, there are other clothing options that will keep you both comfortable and stylish.
featureContentItems.socialDescription: While it's tempting to wear sweats on red-eye flights, there are other clothing options that will keep you both comfortable and fashionable.

fields.name: Lauren Zwanziger
fields.shortBio: Nashville native Lauren Zwanziger captures her life of travel and fashion in her blog, [The Transatlantic](http://www.the-transatlantic.com/).
fields.bio: Nashville native Lauren Zwanziger captures her life of travel and fashion in her blog, [The Transatlantic](http://www.the-transatlantic.com/). Inspired by 15+ years of traveling overseas, Lauren launched her blog in October 2013 to share her adventures. She uses the site to create a visual escape, finding beauty in the ordinary and reality in the extraordinary.

featureContentItems.hed: Why the Highest Peak in Kansas Isn’t Really a Peak
featureContentItems.dek: In this week's Maphead column, Ken Jennings explains why Kansas's highest mountain is hardly even a hill.
featureContentItems.body:
[#image: /photos/54d3f8d6d14554241344fa33]||||||





Sometimes the [highest point in a U.S. state](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2014-11-10/maphead-ken-jennings-inyo-county-california-elevation) is a dramatic peak. But in legendarily flat Kansas, it's barely a hill. You won't need harnesses and pitons to get to the top of "Mount" Sunflower, in Western Kansas. At its summit, you'll be towering above the entire state—but you probably won't even notice. 


[#iframe: https://www.google.com/maps/embed?pb=!1m18!1m12!1m3!1d6348206.957607!2d-102.03724439999999!3d39.02191860000001!2m3!1f0!2f0!3f0!3m2!1i1024!2i768!4f13.1!3m3!1m2!1s0x870b607a03decb49%3A0x3fa549ae39b46d47!2sMt+Sunflower%2C+Weskan%2C+KS+67762!5e0!3m2!1sen!2sus!4v1423178166548](600x450)||||||





__Kansas isn't as flat as you think.__

In a 2003 study published in the Annals of Improbable Research, a trio of geographers used a 1:250,000-scale digital model of Kansas to mathematically prove that the state is, as is often said, flatter than a pancake. But that doesn't mean the pancake is a perfectly horizontal one. In fact, it's tipped gradually but consistently upward toward the High Plains, gaining over 3,000 feet in elevation from the southeast to the northwest.

__One state's high point is another state's lowest.__

As a result, Kansas's highest point is in Wallace County, just a ten-minute walk from the Colorado state line. But the dizzying heights of upper Kansas are nothing once you get to into Colorado and the foothills of the Rockies. Head sixty miles north along the border and you'll hit the Arikaree River, which is actually the lowest point in the state of Colorado.

__Stop by if you're ever in the middle of nowhere.__

The highpoint is an hour away from even the tiniest nearby towns, so no one ever stumbles on it accidentally. If you want to visit, you'll have to make your way from Interstate 70 to a state highway to a gravel road, then across a cattle guard onto the dirt roads of a privately owned ranch. Don't worry about trespassing! The Harold family, which has homesteaded here since 1905, welcomes "hikers" to Mount Sunflower. 

__At least there's an actual sunflower.__

Try not to be disappointed when you drive up to the peak. Mount Sunflower is a barely noticeable rise in the middle of a field. On "top" you'll find a sculpture of a sunflower made from railroad spikes, a picnic table, a collection of license plates supplied by visitors, and a mailbox that contains a guest register and a neighborly invitation to stop by the ranch house and tell the Harolds "about your trails and tribulations to the lofty summit." It may not be Everest, but over a thousand weary pilgrims show up every single year.

*Explore the world's oddities every week with [Ken Jennings](http://www.ken-jennings.com/), and check out his book [Maphead ](http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1439167176/ref=as_li_qf_sp_asin_tl?ie=UTF8&tag=kenjenninconf-20&linkCode=as2&camp=217145&creative=399373&creativeASIN=1439167176) for more geography trivia.*
featureContentItems.seoTitle: Why the Highest Peak in Kansas Isn’t Really a Peak
featureContentItems.seoDescription: In this week's Maphead column, Ken Jennings explains why Kansas's highest mountain is hardly even a hill.
featureContentItems.socialTitle: Why the Highest Peak in Kansas Isn’t Really a Peak

fields.name: Ken Jennings
fields.shortBio: Ken Jennings is a 74-time *Jeopardy!* champion and the bestselling author of seven books, including *Maphead.*
fields.bio: Ken Jennings grew up in Seoul, South Korea, where he became a daily devotee of the quiz show *Jeopardy!* In 2004, he successfully auditioned for a spot on the show and went on an unprecedented seventy-four game victory streak worth $2.52 million. Jennings’s book *Brainiac*, about his *Jeopardy!* adventures, was a critically acclaimed *New York Times* bestseller, as were his follow-up books *Maphead* and *Because I Said So!*  His latest project is a series of books for bright kids, *The Junior Genius Guides*.  Jennings lives in Seattle with his wife, Mindy, his son, Dylan, his daughter, Caitlin, and a small excitable dog named Chance.

featureContentItems.body:
[#image: /photos/53e2ec15dddaa35c30f6497c]||||||

For the huge number of Americans who don't live in a big city, flying internationally often means scrambling to make a connecting flight at another airport. It's a high-stress situation, but one that can be avoided if you're smart about planning your trip. Here are three major airports to avoid if you have to make an international connection—you might just save yourself from getting a major headache before that long flight.



**Chicago: O'Hare International Airport**



Chicago's largest airport has added several runways over the past few years (with one more to come in 2015), leading to fewer delays. Unfortunately, that doesn't change the less-than-ideal terminal setup when it comes to flights abroad. All international arrivals go into Terminal 5, but once you've passed through customs and immigration, you still have to hop a train to make your connection at domestic terminals 1, 2, or 3.







Fortunately, it's a little bit easier if you're flying out of O’Hare. All of the international departures for American and United operate from the airport’s domestic terminals (1, 2 and 3), along with some—but not all—of United and American's biggest partner airlines. But if you're connecting from American to British Airways, you'll still have to make the trek to Terminal 5.







**New York City: John F. Kennedy International Airport**



In addition to perennial delays, JFK's terminal structure often leads to headaches for international travelers. The airport has six distinct buildings, only two of which are connected behind security; and with four (soon to be five) customs facilities, navigating can get confusing quickly. Let's say you're flying on JetBlue, one of JFK's airline hubs, and arrive at Terminal 4; you have to go through customs and immigration before taking the AirTrain to Terminal 5 for a domestic connection. (JetBlue passengers will soon get a reprieve: In the coming months, the airline will open its own customs facility in Terminal 5, making for an easier trek.)



JFK's other large airline hub is Delta, and the situation there is also a pain. International flights arrive at Terminal 4 but many domestic flights operate out of Terminal 2; to get from one to the other, you have to take a ride on the "JFK Jitney," a bus connecting the terminals. (At least it's behind security.) An even bigger problem is connecting to partner airlines such as Air France and Alitalia, which are in a totally different terminal from Delta. The same goes for American and British Airways. If you absolutely _must_ connect at JFK, give yourself plenty of time between flights.



**Los Angeles: LAX**



Travelers have long grumbled about the difficult connecting situation at LAX. The airport has no fewer than eight distinct terminals and few are connected behind security. Each domestic airline is located in its own terminal (some even have flights leaving from multiple terminals), while most international airlines operate from either Terminal 2 or the Tom Bradley International Terminal. That can mean long walks or waiting for a bus to take you around the loop, as well as an additional security check-in.







Luckily, the situation will improve in the next few years: The Bradley Terminal is currently undergoing a big modernization project, scheduled for completion in 2019. One of the improvements being made is an easier connection between the international hub and Terminal 4, where American is located. That should help speed Oneworld Alliance connections, but Delta and United will still be far from their partners.



**Related CNTraveler.com stories:**



[Flights to Hawaii and JFK's T5i: The First of Many Changes for JetBlue](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2012/06/jet-blue-new-jfk-airport-terminal-t5i-hawaii-060512)



[Smart Tips for Avoiding a Missed-Flight Nightmare](http://www.cntraveler.com/perrin-post/2013/09/three-tips-to-avoid-a-missed-flight-nightmare)



[The Art of the Airport Layover](http://www.cntraveler.com/perrin-post/2009/09/airport-layover)
featureContentItems.dek: Nobody likes the hassle of making a connecting flight on a trip abroad. But if you avoid these three major airports, you might just save yourself some time (and stress).
featureContentItems.hed: The Worst Airports for International Connections

fields.name: Brett Snyder
fields.bio: Brett Snyder is the author of the award-winning airline industry blog, “The Cranky Flier," and president and chief airline dork of Cranky Concierge air travel assistance, for which he has been named one of the Top Travel Specialists for the past three years by *Conde Nast Traveler*. He is a contributing editor for PlaneBusiness and he writes for both CNTraveler.com and the Intuit Small Business Blog. Snyder previously worked in pricing, marketing and strategy roles with several airlines, including America West and United. In 2005, Snyder created the travel search site for leading comparison shopping company PriceGrabber.com. Snyder graduated from The George Washington University with a bachelor’s in business in 1999 and Master of Business Administration from Stanford University in 2004.
